resp_chest_pain.description: Chest pain, chest tightness, pressure sensation, breathlessness
resp_chest_pain.impression: Chest discomfort may have a cardiac component and requires close monitoring.
nurse_actions: Monitor blood pressure, pulse, and oxygen saturation every 30 minutes.
Keep the patient in a semi-upright position.
Limit physical exertion and ensure adequate rest.
escalation: Chest pain persisting longer than 20 minutes.
Associated sweating, nausea, or worsening breathlessness.
medicines: Do not initiate cardiac medications without physician evaluation.

general.description: Non-specific cardiovascular symptoms or risk monitoring
general.impression: Cardiac involvement cannot be ruled out and should be observed.
nurse_actions: Monitor vital signs regularly.
Observe for any new chest discomfort or palpitations.
escalation: Development of chest pain or abnormal vital signs.
medicines: Avoid starting cardiac medications without medical review.

fever_cough.impression: Respiratory tract infection is likely contributing to the patientâ€™s symptoms.
nurse_actions: Monitor respiratory rate and oxygen saturation.
Encourage upright positioning to ease breathing.
medicines: Do not initiate respiratory medications without physician advice.

viral_urti.description: Cold, runny nose, headache, mild fever, upper respiratory symptoms
viral_urti.impression: Upper respiratory tract infection of likely viral origin is suspected.
nurse_actions: Monitor temperature and respiratory comfort.
Encourage oral fluids and adequate rest.
escalation: Development of breathing difficulty or chest discomfort.
medicines: Avoid starting medications without physician evaluation.

general.impression: Respiratory status requires observation for any progression.
nurse_actions: Observe breathing pattern and comfort.
escalation: Onset of breathlessness or persistent cough.
medicines: Do not start respiratory drugs without review.

viral_fever.description: Fever, headache, body aches, cold symptoms for 1 to 3 days
viral_fever.impression: An acute viral illness is likely based on the symptom pattern.
nurse_actions: Monitor body temperature periodically.
Encourage adequate hydration and rest.
escalation: High-grade fever persisting more than 3 days.
New symptoms such as rash, vomiting, or breathing difficulty.
medicines: Avoid initiating medications without medical assessment.

general.description: General medical symptoms without clear system involvement
general.impression: General medical observation is required to monitor symptom progression.
nurse_actions: Monitor vital signs and overall condition.

fever_cough.description: Child with fever, cough, or cold symptoms
fever_cough.impression: Pediatric respiratory infection is suspected and requires close observation.
nurse_actions: Ensure adequate fluid intake.
Monitor temperature every 4 hours.
medicines: Do not administer medications without pediatrician approval.

general.impression: Pediatric evaluation and observation are required.
nurse_actions: Observe child closely for changes in behavior or feeding.

abdomen_gastro.impression: Gastrointestinal involvement is suspected based on symptoms.
nurse_actions: Keep the patient nil by mouth until reviewed.
Monitor abdominal discomfort and vomiting.
Monitor abdominal symptoms.
medicines: Do not start GI medications without review.

general.impression: Neurological causes should be considered and monitored.
nurse_actions: Monitor level of consciousness and orientation.
escalation: Altered mental status or worsening neurological symptoms.
medicines: Avoid neurological medications without specialist input.
